classes.name: org.bukkit.generator.BlockPopulator
classes.comment_text:
A block populator is responsible for generating a small area of blocks.

For example, generating glowstone inside the nether or generating dungeons full of treasure

methods.name: populate
methods.comment_text:
Populates an area of blocks at or around the given chunk.

The chunks on each side of the specified chunk must already exist; that is, there must be one north, east, south and west of the specified chunk. The "corner" chunks may not exist, in which scenario the populator should record any changes required for those chunks and perform the changes when they are ready.

classes.name: org.bukkit.help.IndexHelpTopic
classes.comment_text:
This help topic generates a list of other help topics. This class is useful for adding your own index help topics. To enforce a particular order, use a sorted collection.

If a preamble is provided to the constructor, that text will be displayed before the first item in the index.

methods.name: setTopicsCollection
methods.comment_text: Sets the contents of the internal allTopics collection.

methods.name: buildPreamble
methods.comment_text:
Builds the topic preamble. Override this method to change how the index
 preamble looks.

parameters.name: sender
parameters.comment_text: The command sender requesting the preamble.

methods.name: buildIndexLine
methods.comment_text:
Builds individual lines in the index topic. Override this method to
 change how index lines are rendered.

parameters.name: sender
parameters.comment_text: The command sender requesting the index line.

parameters.name: topic
parameters.comment_text: The topic to render into an index line.

classes.name: org.bukkit.help.HelpTopicFactory
classes.comment_text:
A HelpTopicFactory is used to create custom {@link HelpTopic} objects from commands that inherit from a common base class or have executors that inherit from a common base class. You can use a custom HelpTopic to change the way all the commands in your plugin display in the help. If your plugin implements a complex permissions system, a custom help topic may also be appropriate.

To automatically bind your plugin's commands to your custom HelpTopic implementation, first make sure all your commands or executors derive from a custom base class (it doesn't have to do anything). Next implement a custom HelpTopicFactory that accepts your custom command base class and instantiates an instance of your custom HelpTopic from it. Finally, register your HelpTopicFactory against your command base class using the {@link HelpMap#registerHelpTopicFactory(Class, HelpTopicFactory)} method.

As the help system iterates over all registered commands to make help topics, it first checks to see if there is a HelpTopicFactory registered for the command's base class. If so, the factory is used to make a help topic rather than a generic help topic. If no factory is found for the command's base class and the command derives from {@link org.bukkit.command.PluginCommand}, then the type of the command's executor is inspected looking for a registered HelpTopicFactory. Finally, if no factory is found, a generic help topic is created for the command.

methods.name: createTopic
methods.comment_text:
This method accepts a command deriving from a custom command base class
 and constructs a custom HelpTopic for it.

parameters.name: command
parameters.comment_text: The custom command to build a help topic for.

classes.name: org.bukkit.help.HelpTopicComparator
classes.comment_text:
Used to impose a custom total ordering on help topics.

All topics are listed in alphabetic order, but topics that start with a slash come after topics that don't.

classes.name: org.bukkit.help.HelpTopic
classes.comment_text:
HelpTopic implementations are displayed to the user when the user uses the /help command.

Custom implementations of this class can work at two levels. A simple implementation only needs to set the value of {@code name}, {@code shortText}, and {@code fullText} in the constructor. This base class will take care of the rest.

Complex implementations can be created by overriding the behavior of all the methods in this class.

methods.name: canSee
methods.comment_text:
Determines if a {@link Player} is allowed to see this help topic.

HelpTopic implementations should take server administrator wishes into account as set by the {@link HelpTopic#amendCanSee(String)} function.

methods.name: amendCanSee
methods.comment_text:
Allows the server administrator to override the permission required to see a help topic.

HelpTopic implementations should take this into account when determining topic visibility on the {@link HelpTopic#canSee(org.bukkit.command.CommandSender)} function.

parameters.name: amendedPermission
parameters.comment_text:
The permission node the server administrator
     wishes to apply to this topic.

methods.name: getName
methods.comment_text: Returns the name of this help topic.

methods.name: getShortText
methods.comment_text: Returns a brief description that will be displayed in the topic index.

methods.name: getFullText
methods.comment_text:
Returns the full description of this help topic that is displayed when the user requests this topic's details.

The result will be paginated to properly fit the user's client.

parameters.name: forWho
parameters.comment_text:
The player or console requesting the full text. Useful
     for further security trimming the command's full text based on
     sub-permissions in custom implementations.

methods.name: amendTopic
methods.comment_text:
Allows the server admin (or another plugin) to add or replace the contents of a help topic.

A null in either parameter will leave that part of the topic unchanged. In either amending parameter, the string {@literal } is replaced with the existing contents in the help topic. Use this to append or prepend additional content into an automatically generated help topic.

parameters.name: amendedShortText
parameters.comment_text:
The new topic short text to use, or null to
     leave alone.

parameters.name: amendedFullText
parameters.comment_text:
The new topic full text to use, or null to leave
     alone.

methods.name: applyAmendment
methods.comment_text:
Developers implementing their own custom HelpTopic implementations can
 use this utility method to ensure their implementations comply with the
 expected behavior of the {@link HelpTopic#amendTopic(String, String)}
 method.

parameters.name: baseText
parameters.comment_text: The existing text of the help topic.

parameters.name: amendment
parameters.comment_text: The amending text from the amendTopic() method.

classes.name: org.bukkit.help.HelpMap
classes.comment_text:
The HelpMap tracks all help topics registered in a Bukkit server. When the server starts up or is reloaded, help is processed and topics are added in the following order:
  1. General topics are loaded from the help.yml
  2. Plugins load and optionally call {@code addTopic()}
  3. Registered plugin commands are processed by {@link HelpTopicFactory} objects to create topics
  4. Topic contents are amended as directed in help.yml

methods.name: getHelpTopic
methods.comment_text: Returns a help topic for a given topic name.

parameters.name: topicName
parameters.comment_text: The help topic name to look up.

methods.name: getHelpTopics
methods.comment_text: Returns a collection of all the registered help topics.

methods.name: addTopic
methods.comment_text: Adds a topic to the server's help index.

parameters.name: topic
parameters.comment_text: The new help topic to add.

methods.name: clear
methods.comment_text:
Clears out the contents of the help index. Normally called during
 server reload.

methods.name: registerHelpTopicFactory
methods.comment_text:
Associates a {@link HelpTopicFactory} object with given command base
 class. Plugins typically call this method during {@code onLoad()}. Once
 registered, the custom HelpTopicFactory will be used to create a custom
 {@link HelpTopic} for all commands deriving from the {@code
 commandClass} base class, or all commands deriving from {@link
 org.bukkit.command.PluginCommand} who's executor derives from {@code
 commandClass} base class.

parameters.name: commandClass
factory
parameters.comment_text:
The {@link HelpTopicFactory} implementation to associate
     with the {@code commandClass}.

methods.name: getIgnoredPlugins
methods.comment_text:
Gets the list of plugins the server administrator has chosen to exclude
 from the help index. Plugin authors who choose to directly extend
 {@link org.bukkit.command.Command} instead of {@link
 org.bukkit.command.PluginCommand} will need to check this collection in
 their {@link HelpTopicFactory} implementations to ensure they meet the
 server administrator's expectations.

classes.name: org.bukkit.help.GenericCommandHelpTopic
classes.comment_text:
Lacking an alternative, the help system will create instances of
 GenericCommandHelpTopic for each command in the server's CommandMap. You
 can use this class as a base class for custom help topics, or as an example
 for how to write your own.

methods.name: setItem
methods.comment_text:
Stores the ItemStack at the given index of the inventory.

Indexes 0 through 8 refer to the hotbar. 9 through 35 refer to the main inventory, counting up from 9 at the top left corner of the inventory, moving to the right, and moving to the row below it back on the left side when it reaches the end of the row. It follows the same path in the inventory like you would read a book.

Indexes 36 through 39 refer to the armor slots. Though you can set armor with this method using these indexes, you are encouraged to use the provided methods for those slots.

Index 40 refers to the off hand (shield) item slot. Though you can set off hand with this method using this index, you are encouraged to use the provided method for this slot.

If you attempt to use this method with an index less than 0 or greater than 40, an ArrayIndexOutOfBounds exception will be thrown.

parameters.name: index
parameters.comment_text: The index where to put the ItemStack

classes.name: org.bukkit.inventory.ItemFactory
classes.comment_text:
An instance of the ItemFactory can be obtained with {@link Server#getItemFactory()}.

The ItemFactory is solely responsible for creating item meta containers to apply on item stacks.

methods.name: isApplicable
methods.comment_text:
This method checks the item meta to confirm that it is applicable (no data lost if applied) to the specified ItemStack.

A {@link SkullMeta} would not be valid for a sword, but a normal {@link ItemMeta} from an enchanted dirt block would.

parameters.name: stack

throws.name: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
throws.comment_text:
if the meta was not created by this
     factory

methods.name: isApplicable

This method checks the item meta to confirm that it is applicable (no data lost if applied) to the specified Material.

A {@link SkullMeta} would not be valid for a sword, but a normal {@link ItemMeta} from an enchanted dirt block would.

throws.comment_text:
if the meta was not created by this
     factory

methods.name: equals
methods.comment_text: This method is used to compare two item meta data objects.

parameters.name: meta1
parameters.comment_text: First meta to compare, and may be null to indicate no data

parameters.name: meta2

Second meta to compare, and may be null to indicate no
     data

throws.name: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
throws.comment_text:
if either meta was not created by this
     factory

methods.name: asMetaFor
methods.comment_text:
Returns an appropriate item meta for the specified stack.

The item meta returned will always be a valid meta for a given ItemStack of the specified material. It may be a more or less specific meta, and could also be the same meta or meta type as the parameter. The item meta returned will also always be the most appropriate meta.

Example, if a {@link SkullMeta} is being applied to a book, this method would return a {@link BookMeta} containing all information in the specified meta that is applicable to an {@link ItemMeta}, the highest common interface.

parameters.name: stack
parameters.comment_text: the stack to convert the meta for

throws.name: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
throws.comment_text:
if the specified meta was not created
     by this factory

classes.name: org.bukkit.inventory.InventoryView
classes.comment_text:
Represents a view linking two inventories and a single player (whose inventory may or may not be one of the two).

Note: If you implement this interface but fail to satisfy the expected contracts of certain methods, there's no guarantee that the game will work as it should.

methods.name: getTopInventory
methods.comment_text: Get the upper inventory involved in this transaction.

methods.name: getBottomInventory
methods.comment_text: Get the lower inventory involved in this transaction.

methods.name: getPlayer
methods.comment_text: Get the player viewing.

methods.name: getType
methods.comment_text:
Determine the type of inventory involved in the transaction. This
 indicates the window style being shown. It will never return PLAYER,
 since that is common to all windows.

methods.name: setItem
methods.comment_text:
Sets one item in this inventory view by its raw slot ID.

Note: If slot ID -999 is chosen, it may be expected that the item is dropped on the ground. This is not required behaviour, however.

parameters.name: slot
parameters.comment_text: The ID as returned by InventoryClickEvent.getRawSlot()

parameters.name: item
parameters.comment_text: The new item to put in the slot, or null to clear it.

methods.name: getItem
methods.comment_text: Gets one item in this inventory view by its raw slot ID.

parameters.name: slot
parameters.comment_text: The ID as returned by InventoryClickEvent.getRawSlot()

methods.name: setCursor
methods.comment_text: Sets the item on the cursor of one of the viewing players.

parameters.name: item
parameters.comment_text:
The item to put on the cursor, or null to remove the item
     on their cursor.

methods.name: getCursor
methods.comment_text: Get the item on the cursor of one of the viewing players.

methods.name: convertSlot
methods.comment_text:
Converts a raw slot ID into its local slot ID into whichever of the two inventories the slot points to.

If the raw slot refers to the upper inventory, it will be returned unchanged and thus be suitable for getTopInventory().getItem(); if it refers to the lower inventory, the output will differ from the input and be suitable for getBottomInventory().getItem().

methods.name: close
methods.comment_text: Closes the inventory view.

methods.name: countSlots
methods.comment_text:
Check the total number of slots in this view, combining the upper and lower inventories.

Note though that it's possible for this to be greater than the sum of the two inventories if for example some slots are not being used.

methods.name: setProperty
methods.comment_text:
Sets an extra property of this inventory if supported by that
 inventory, for example the state of a progress bar.

parameters.name: value
parameters.comment_text: the new value for the window property

methods.name: getTitle
methods.comment_text: Get the title of this inventory window.

classes.name: org.bukkit.inventory.InventoryView.Property
classes.comment_text: Represents various extra properties of certain inventory windows.

methods.name: getInventory
methods.comment_text: Get the object's inventory.

classes.name: org.bukkit.inventory.Inventory
classes.comment_text:
Interface to the various inventories. Behavior relating to {@link
 Material#AIR} is unspecified.

methods.name: getSize
methods.comment_text: Returns the size of the inventory

methods.name: getMaxStackSize
methods.comment_text: Returns the maximum stack size for an ItemStack in this inventory.

methods.name: setMaxStackSize
methods.comment_text:
This method allows you to change the maximum stack size for an inventory.

Caveats:

  • Not all inventories respect this value.
  • Stacks larger than 127 may be clipped when the world is saved.
  • This value is not guaranteed to be preserved; be sure to set it before every time you want to set a slot over the max stack size.
  • Stacks larger than the default max size for this type of inventory may not display correctly in the client.

parameters.name: size
parameters.comment_text: The new maximum stack size for items in this inventory.

methods.name: getName
methods.comment_text: Returns the name of the inventory

methods.name: getItem
methods.comment_text: Returns the ItemStack found in the slot at the given index

parameters.name: index
parameters.comment_text: The index of the Slot's ItemStack to return

methods.name: setItem
methods.comment_text: Stores the ItemStack at the given index of the inventory.

parameters.name: index
parameters.comment_text: The index where to put the ItemStack

methods.name: addItem
methods.comment_text:
Stores the given ItemStacks in the inventory. This will try to fill existing stacks and empty slots as well as it can.

The returned HashMap contains what it couldn't store, where the key is the index of the parameter, and the value is the ItemStack at that index of the varargs parameter. If all items are stored, it will return an empty HashMap.

If you pass in ItemStacks which exceed the maximum stack size for the Material, first they will be added to partial stacks where Material.getMaxStackSize() is not exceeded, up to Material.getMaxStackSize(). When there are no partial stacks left stacks will be split on Inventory.getMaxStackSize() allowing you to exceed the maximum stack size for that material.

It is known that in some implementations this method will also set the inputted argument amount to the number of that item not placed in slots.

throws.name: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
throws.comment_text: if items or any element in it is null

methods.name: removeItem
methods.comment_text:
Removes the given ItemStacks from the inventory.

It will try to remove 'as much as possible' from the types and amounts you give as arguments.

The returned HashMap contains what it couldn't remove, where the key is the index of the parameter, and the value is the ItemStack at that index of the varargs parameter. If all the given ItemStacks are removed, it will return an empty HashMap.

It is known that in some implementations this method will also set the inputted argument amount to the number of that item not removed from slots.

throws.name: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
throws.comment_text: if items is null

methods.name: getContents
methods.comment_text: Returns all ItemStacks from the inventory

methods.name: setContents
methods.comment_text:
Completely replaces the inventory's contents. Removes all existing
 contents and replaces it with the ItemStacks given in the array.

parameters.name: items
parameters.comment_text:
A complete replacement for the contents; the length must
     be less than or equal to {@link #getSize()}.

throws.name: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
throws.comment_text:
If the array has more items than the
     inventory.

methods.name: getStorageContents
methods.comment_text:
Return the contents from the section of the inventory where items can reasonably be expected to be stored. In most cases this will represent the entire inventory, but in some cases it may exclude armor or result slots.
It is these contents which will be used for add / contains / remove methods which look for a specific stack.

methods.name: setStorageContents
methods.comment_text: Put the given ItemStacks into the storage slots

parameters.name: items
parameters.comment_text: The ItemStacks to use as storage contents

throws.name: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
throws.comment_text:
If the array has more items than the
 inventory.

methods.name: contains
methods.comment_text:
Checks if the inventory contains any ItemStacks with the given
 material.

throws.name: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
throws.comment_text: if material is null

methods.name: contains
methods.comment_text:
Checks if the inventory contains any ItemStacks matching the given ItemStack.

This will only return true if both the type and the amount of the stack match.

methods.name: contains
methods.comment_text:
Checks if the inventory contains any ItemStacks with the given
 material, adding to at least the minimum amount specified.

throws.name: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
throws.comment_text: if material is null

methods.name: contains
methods.comment_text:
Checks if the inventory contains at least the minimum amount specified of exactly matching ItemStacks.

An ItemStack only counts if both the type and the amount of the stack match.

parameters.name: amount
parameters.comment_text: how many identical stacks to check for

methods.name: containsAtLeast
methods.comment_text:
Checks if the inventory contains ItemStacks matching the given
 ItemStack whose amounts sum to at least the minimum amount specified.

methods.name: all
methods.comment_text:
Returns a HashMap with all slots and ItemStacks in the inventory with the given Material.

The HashMap contains entries where, the key is the slot index, and the value is the ItemStack in that slot. If no matching ItemStack with the given Material is found, an empty map is returned.

throws.name: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
throws.comment_text: if material is null

methods.name: all
methods.comment_text:
Finds all slots in the inventory containing any ItemStacks with the given ItemStack. This will only match slots if both the type and the amount of the stack match

The HashMap contains entries where, the key is the slot index, and the value is the ItemStack in that slot. If no matching ItemStack with the given Material is found, an empty map is returned.

methods.name: first
methods.comment_text:
Finds the first slot in the inventory containing an ItemStack with the
 given material

throws.name: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
throws.comment_text: if material is null

methods.name: first
methods.comment_text:
Returns the first slot in the inventory containing an ItemStack with
 the given stack. This will only match a slot if both the type and the
 amount of the stack match

methods.name: firstEmpty
methods.comment_text: Returns the first empty Slot.

methods.name: remove
methods.comment_text: Removes all stacks in the inventory matching the given material.

throws.name: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
throws.comment_text: if material is null

methods.name: remove
methods.comment_text:
Removes all stacks in the inventory matching the given stack.

This will only match a slot if both the type and the amount of the stack match

methods.name: clear
methods.comment_text: Clears out a particular slot in the index.

methods.name: clear
methods.comment_text: Clears out the whole Inventory.

methods.name: getViewers
methods.comment_text:
Gets a list of players viewing the inventory. Note that a player is
 considered to be viewing their own inventory and internal crafting
 screen even when said inventory is not open. They will normally be
 considered to be viewing their inventory even when they have a
 different inventory screen open, but it's possible for customized
 inventory screens to exclude the viewer's inventory, so this should
 never be assumed to be non-empty.

methods.name: getTitle
methods.comment_text: Returns the title of this inventory.

methods.name: getType
methods.comment_text: Returns what type of inventory this is.

methods.name: getHolder
methods.comment_text: Gets the block or entity belonging to the open inventory

methods.name: iterator
methods.comment_text:
Returns an iterator starting at the given index. If the index is
 positive, then the first call to next() will return the item at that
 index; if it is negative, the first call to previous will return the
 item at index (getSize() + index).

methods.name: getLocation
methods.comment_text:
Get the location of the block or entity which corresponds to this inventory. May return null if this container
 was custom created or is a virtual / subcontainer.

methods.name: setPatternColor
methods.comment_text:
Sets the color of the fish's pattern.

Setting this when hasVariant() returns false will initialize all other values to unspecified defaults.

methods.name: getBodyColor
methods.comment_text:
Gets the color of the fish's body.

Plugins should check that hasVariant() returns true before calling this method.

methods.name: setBodyColor
methods.comment_text:
Sets the color of the fish's body.

Setting this when hasVariant() returns false will initialize all other values to unspecified defaults.

methods.name: getPattern
methods.comment_text:
Gets the fish's pattern.

Plugins should check that hasVariant() returns true before calling this method.

methods.name: setPattern
methods.comment_text:
Sets the fish's pattern.

Setting this when hasVariant() returns false will initialize all other values to unspecified defaults.

methods.name: hasVariant
methods.comment_text:
Checks for existence of a variant tag indicating a specific fish will be
 spawned.

Gets an immutable list containing all custom potion effects applied to this potion.

Plugins should check that hasCustomEffects() returns true before calling this method.

true if any existing effect of the same type should be
 overwritten

methods.comment_text: Removes a custom potion effect from this potion.

Moves a potion effect to the top of the potion effect list.

This causes the client to display the potion effect in the potion's name.

parameters.name: type
parameters.comment_text: the potion effect type to move

methods.name: clearCustomEffects
methods.comment_text: Removes all custom potion effects from this potion.

methods.name: hasColor
methods.comment_text: Checks for existence of a potion color.

methods.name: getColor
methods.comment_text:
Gets the potion color that is set. A custom potion color will alter the display of the potion in an inventory slot.

Plugins should check that hasColor() returns true before calling this method.

methods.name: setColor
methods.comment_text:
Sets the potion color. A custom potion color will alter the display of
 the potion in an inventory slot.

methods.name: isScaling

methods.name: setScaling

methods.name: hasLocationName

methods.name: getLocationName

Plugins should check that hasLocationName() returns true before calling this method.

methods.name: setLocationName
methods.comment_text:
Sets the location name. A custom map color will alter the display of the
 map in an inventory slot.

methods.name: hasColor
methods.comment_text: Checks for existence of a map color.

methods.name: getColor
methods.comment_text:
Gets the map color that is set. A custom map color will alter the display of the map in an inventory slot.

Plugins should check that hasColor() returns true before calling this method.

methods.name: setColor
methods.comment_text:
Sets the map color. A custom map color will alter the display of the map
 in an inventory slot.

classes.name: org.bukkit.inventory.meta.LeatherArmorMeta
classes.comment_text:
Represents leather armor ({@link Material#LEATHER_BOOTS}, {@link
 Material#LEATHER_CHESTPLATE}, {@link Material#LEATHER_HELMET}, or {@link
 Material#LEATHER_LEGGINGS}) that can be colored.

methods.name: getColor
methods.comment_text:
Gets the color of the armor. If it has not been set otherwise, it will

the color to set. Setting it to null is equivalent to
     setting it to {@link ItemFactory#getDefaultLeatherColor()}.

 recipes.

methods.comment_text: Adds new recipe to the end of the book.

classes.name: org.bukkit.inventory.meta.ItemMeta
classes.comment_text:
This type represents the storage mechanism for auxiliary item data.

An implementation will handle the creation and application for ItemMeta. This class should not be implemented by a plugin in a live environment.

methods.name: hasDisplayName
methods.comment_text: Checks for existence of a display name.

methods.name: getDisplayName
methods.comment_text:
Gets the display name that is set.

Plugins should check that hasDisplayName() returns true before calling this method.

methods.name: setDisplayName
methods.comment_text: Sets the display name.

methods.name: hasLocalizedName
methods.comment_text: Checks for existence of a localized name.

methods.name: getLocalizedName
methods.comment_text:
Gets the localized display name that is set.

Plugins should check that hasLocalizedName() returns true before calling this method.

methods.name: setLocalizedName
methods.comment_text: Sets the localized name.

methods.name: hasLore
methods.comment_text: Checks for existence of lore.

methods.name: getLore
methods.comment_text:
Gets the lore that is set.

Plugins should check if hasLore() returns true before calling this method.

methods.name: setLore
methods.comment_text:
Sets the lore for this item. 
 Removes lore when given null.

methods.name: hasEnchants
methods.comment_text: Checks for the existence of any enchantments.

methods.name: hasEnchant

methods.name: getEnchantLevel
methods.comment_text: Checks for the level of the specified enchantment.

methods.name: getEnchants
methods.comment_text:
Returns a copy the enchantments in this ItemMeta.
Returns an empty map if none.

methods.name: addEnchant

parameters.name: ignoreLevelRestriction
parameters.comment_text:
this indicates the enchantment should be
     applied, ignoring the level limit

methods.name: hasConflictingEnchant
methods.comment_text:
Checks if the specified enchantment conflicts with any enchantments in
 this ItemMeta.

methods.name: addItemFlags
methods.comment_text: Set itemflags which should be ignored when rendering a ItemStack in the Client. This Method does silently ignore double set itemFlags.

parameters.name: itemFlags
parameters.comment_text: The hideflags which shouldn't be rendered

methods.name: removeItemFlags
methods.comment_text: Remove specific set of itemFlags. This tells the Client it should render it again. This Method does silently ignore double removed itemFlags.

methods.name: getItemFlags
methods.comment_text: Get current set itemFlags. The collection returned is unmodifiable.

methods.name: hasItemFlag
methods.comment_text: Check if the specified flag is present on this item.

methods.comment_text:
Return if the unbreakable tag is true. An unbreakable item will not lose
 durability.

methods.name: setUnbreakable
methods.comment_text: Sets the unbreakable tag. An unbreakable item will not lose durability.

An iterable object whose iterator yields the desired

this indicates the enchantment should be

methods.name: setDamage
methods.comment_text: Sets the damage

classes.name: org.bukkit.inventory.meta.BookMeta
classes.comment_text:
Represents a book ({@link Material#WRITABLE_BOOK} or {@link
 Material#WRITTEN_BOOK}) that can have a title, an author, and pages.

methods.name: hasTitle
methods.comment_text: Checks for the existence of a title in the book.

methods.name: getTitle
methods.comment_text:
Gets the title of the book.

Plugins should check that hasTitle() returns true before calling this method.

methods.name: setTitle
methods.comment_text:
Sets the title of the book.

Limited to 16 characters. Removes title when given null.

methods.name: hasAuthor
methods.comment_text: Checks for the existence of an author in the book.

methods.name: getAuthor
methods.comment_text:
Gets the author of the book.

Plugins should check that hasAuthor() returns true before calling this method.

methods.name: setAuthor
methods.comment_text: Sets the author of the book. Removes author when given null.

methods.name: hasGeneration
methods.comment_text: Checks for the existence of generation level in the book.

methods.name: getGeneration
methods.comment_text:
Gets the generation of the book.

Plugins should check that hasGeneration() returns true before calling this method.

methods.name: setGeneration
methods.comment_text: Sets the generation of the book. Removes generation when given null.

methods.name: hasPages
methods.comment_text: Checks for the existence of pages in the book.

methods.name: getPage
methods.comment_text: Gets the specified page in the book. The given page must exist.

methods.name: setPage
methods.comment_text:
Sets the specified page in the book. Pages of the book must be contiguous.

The data can be up to 256 characters in length, additional characters are truncated.

parameters.name: data
parameters.comment_text: the data to set for that page

methods.name: getPages
methods.comment_text: Gets all the pages in the book.

methods.name: setPages
methods.comment_text:
Clears the existing book pages, and sets the book to use the provided
 pages. Maximum 50 pages with 256 characters per page.

parameters.name: pages
parameters.comment_text: A list of pages to set the book to use

methods.name: setPages
methods.comment_text:
Clears the existing book pages, and sets the book to use the provided
 pages. Maximum 50 pages with 256 characters per page.

parameters.name: pages
parameters.comment_text: A list of strings, each being a page

methods.name: addPage
methods.comment_text:
Adds new pages to the end of the book. Up to a maximum of 50 pages with
 256 characters per page.

parameters.name: pages
parameters.comment_text: A list of strings, each being a page

methods.name: getPageCount
methods.comment_text: Gets the number of pages in the book.

classes.name: org.bukkit.inventory.meta.BookMeta.Generation
classes.comment_text: Represents the generation (or level of copying) of a written book

methods.name: hasBlockState
methods.comment_text:
Returns whether the item has a block state currently
 attached to it.

methods.name: getBlockState
methods.comment_text:
Returns the currently attached block state for this
 item or creates a new one if one doesn't exist.

 The state is a copy, it must be set back (or to another
 item) with {@link #setBlockState(org.bukkit.block.BlockState)}

methods.name: setBlockState
methods.comment_text: Attaches a copy of the passed block state to the item.

parameters.name: blockState
parameters.comment_text: the block state to attach to the block.

methods.name: getBaseColor
methods.comment_text: Returns the base color for this banner

methods.name: setBaseColor
methods.comment_text: Sets the base color for this banner

methods.name: getPatterns
methods.comment_text: Returns a list of patterns on this banner

methods.name: setPatterns
methods.comment_text: Sets the patterns used on this banner

methods.name: addPattern
methods.comment_text:
Adds a new pattern on top of the existing
 patterns

methods.name: getPattern
methods.comment_text: Returns the pattern at the specified index

methods.name: removePattern
methods.comment_text: Removes the pattern at the specified index

methods.name: setPattern
methods.comment_text: Sets the pattern at the specified index

methods.name: numberOfPatterns
methods.comment_text:
Returns the number of patterns on this
 banner

classes.name: org.bukkit.loot.LootTables
classes.comment_text: This enum holds a list of all known {@link LootTable}s offered by Mojang. This list is not guaranteed to be accurate in future versions. See the Minecraft Wiki for more information on loot tables.

methods.name: getLootTable
methods.comment_text:
Get the {@link LootTable} corresponding to this constant. This is
 equivalent to calling {@code Bukkit.getLootTable(this.getKey());}.

classes.name: org.bukkit.loot.LootTable
classes.comment_text: LootTables are technical files that represent what items should be in naturally generated containers, what items should be dropped when killing a mob, or what items can be fished. See the Minecraft Wiki for more information.

methods.name: populateLoot
methods.comment_text: Returns a mutable list of loot generated by this LootTable.

parameters.name: random
parameters.comment_text: the random instance to use to generate loot

methods.name: fillInventory
methods.comment_text: Attempt to fill an inventory with this LootTable's loot.

parameters.name: random
parameters.comment_text: the random instance to use to generate loot

classes.name: org.bukkit.loot.LootContext
classes.comment_text:
Represents additional information a {@link LootTable} can use to modify it's
 generated loot.

methods.name: getLocation
methods.comment_text: The {@link Location} to store where the loot will be generated.

methods.name: getLuck
methods.comment_text:
Represents the {@link org.bukkit.potion.PotionEffectType#LUCK} that an
 entity can have. The higher the value the better chance of receiving more
 loot.

methods.name: getLootingModifier
methods.comment_text:
Represents the
 {@link org.bukkit.enchantments.Enchantment#LOOT_BONUS_MOBS} the
 {@link #getKiller()} entity has on their equipped item.

 This value is only set via
 {@link LootContext.Builder#lootingModifier(int)}. If not set, the
 {@link #getKiller()} entity's looting level will be used instead.

methods.name: getLootedEntity
methods.comment_text: Get the {@link Entity} that was killed. Can be null.

methods.name: getKiller
methods.comment_text:
Get the {@link HumanEntity} who killed the {@link #getLootedEntity()}.
 Can be null.

classes.name: org.bukkit.loot.LootContext.Builder
classes.comment_text:
Utility class to make building {@link LootContext} easier. The only
 required argument is {@link Location} with a valid (non-null)
 {@link org.bukkit.World}.

constructors.name: Builder
constructors.comment_text:
Creates a new LootContext.Builder instance to facilitate easy
 creation of {@link LootContext}s.

parameters.name: location
parameters.comment_text: the location the LootContext should use

methods.name: luck
methods.comment_text: Set how much luck to have when generating loot.

methods.name: lootingModifier
methods.comment_text:
Set the {@link org.bukkit.enchantments.Enchantment#LOOT_BONUS_MOBS}
 level equivalent to use when generating loot. Values less than or
 equal to 0 will force the {@link LootTable} to only return a single
 {@link org.bukkit.inventory.ItemStack} per pool.

methods.name: lootedEntity
methods.comment_text: The entity that was killed.

methods.name: killer
methods.comment_text:
Set the {@link org.bukkit.entity.HumanEntity} that killed
 {@link #getLootedEntity()}. This entity will be used to get the
 looting level if {@link #lootingModifier(int)} is not set.

methods.name: build
methods.comment_text:
Create a new {@link LootContext} instance using the supplied
 parameters.

classes.name: org.bukkit.loot.Lootable
classes.comment_text:
Represents a {@link org.bukkit.block.Container} or a {@link org.bukkit.entity.Mob} that can have a loot table.
Container loot will only generate upon opening, and only when the container is first opened.
Entities will only generate loot upon death.

methods.name: setLootTable
methods.comment_text:
Set the loot table for a container or entity.
To remove a loot table use null. Do not use {@link LootTables#EMPTY} to clear a LootTable.

parameters.name: table
parameters.comment_text:
the Loot Table this {@link org.bukkit.block.Container} or
 {@link org.bukkit.entity.Mob} will have.

methods.name: getLootTable
methods.comment_text:
Gets the Loot Table attached to this block or entity.
If an block/entity does not have a loot table, this will return null, NOT an empty loot table.

methods.name: setSeed
methods.comment_text: Set the seed used when this Loot Table generates loot.

parameters.name: seed
parameters.comment_text: the seed to used to generate loot. Default is 0.

methods.name: getSeed
methods.comment_text:
Get the Loot Table's seed.
The seed is used when generating loot.

classes.name: org.bukkit.map.MinecraftFont

constructors.comment_text: Initialize a new MinecraftFont.

fields.name: Font

classes.name: org.bukkit.map.MapView
classes.comment_text: Represents a map item.

methods.name: getId
methods.comment_text:
Get the ID of this map item. Corresponds to the damage value of a map
 in an inventory.

methods.name: isVirtual
methods.comment_text:
Check whether this map is virtual. A map is virtual if its lowermost

methods.name: setCenterX
methods.comment_text: Set the center X position of this map.

methods.name: setCenterZ
methods.comment_text: Set the center Z position of this map.

methods.name: getWorld

Get the world that this map is associated with. Primarily used by the
 internal renderer, but may be used by external renderers. May return
 null if the world the map is associated with is not loaded.

methods.name: setWorld
methods.comment_text:
Set the world that this map is associated with. The world is used by
 the internal renderer, and may also be used by external renderers.

methods.name: getRenderers
methods.comment_text: Get a list of MapRenderers currently in effect.

methods.name: addRenderer
methods.comment_text: Add a renderer to this map.

methods.name: removeRenderer
methods.comment_text: Remove a renderer from this map.

methods.name: isUnlimitedTracking
methods.comment_text:
Whether the map will show a smaller position cursor (true), or no
 position cursor (false) when cursor is outside of map's range.

methods.name: setUnlimitedTracking
methods.comment_text:
Whether the map will show a smaller position cursor (true), or no
 position cursor (false) when cursor is outside of map's range.

classes.name: org.bukkit.map.MapView.Scale
classes.comment_text: An enum representing all possible scales a map can be set to.

methods.name: valueOf
methods.comment_text: Get the scale given the raw value.

methods.name: getValue
methods.comment_text: Get the raw value of this scale level.

classes.name: org.bukkit.map.MapRenderer
classes.comment_text: Represents a renderer for a map.

constructors.name: MapRenderer
constructors.comment_text:
Initialize the map renderer base to be non-contextual. See {@link
 #isContextual()}.

constructors.name: MapRenderer
constructors.comment_text: Initialize the map renderer base with the given contextual status.

parameters.name: contextual
parameters.comment_text:
Whether the renderer is contextual. See {@link
     #isContextual()}.

methods.name: isContextual
methods.comment_text:
Get whether the renderer is contextual, i.e. has different canvases for
 different players.

methods.name: initialize
methods.comment_text: Initialize this MapRenderer for the given map.

methods.name: render
methods.comment_text: Render to the given map.

parameters.name: canvas
parameters.comment_text: The canvas to use for rendering.

parameters.name: player
parameters.comment_text: The player who triggered the rendering.

classes.name: org.bukkit.map.MapPalette
classes.comment_text:
Represents the palette that map items use.

These fields are hee base color ranges. Each entry corresponds to four colors of varying shades with values entry to entry + 3.

methods.name: resizeImage
methods.comment_text: Resize an image to 128x128.

methods.name: imageToBytes
methods.comment_text: Convert an Image to a byte[] using the palette.

methods.name: matchColor
methods.comment_text:
Get the index of the closest matching color in the palette to the given
 color.

parameters.name: r
parameters.comment_text: The red component of the color.

parameters.name: g
parameters.comment_text: The green component of the color.

parameters.name: b
parameters.comment_text: The blue component of the color.

methods.name: matchColor
methods.comment_text:
Get the index of the closest matching color in the palette to the given
 color.

classes.name: org.bukkit.map.MapCanvas
classes.comment_text:
Represents a canvas for drawing to a map. Each canvas is associated with a
 specific {@link MapRenderer} and represents that renderer's layer on the
 map.

methods.name: getMapView
methods.comment_text: Get the map this canvas is attached to.

methods.name: getCursors
methods.comment_text: Get the cursor collection associated with this canvas.

methods.name: setCursors
methods.comment_text:
Set the cursor collection associated with this canvas. This does not
 usually need to be called since a MapCursorCollection is already
 provided.

parameters.name: cursors
parameters.comment_text: The MapCursorCollection to associate with this canvas.

methods.name: setPixel
methods.comment_text: Draw a pixel to the canvas.

methods.name: getPixel
methods.comment_text: Get a pixel from the canvas.

methods.name: getBasePixel
methods.comment_text: Get a pixel from the layers below this canvas.

methods.name: drawImage
methods.comment_text: Draw an image to the map. The image will be clipped if necessary.

parameters.name: x
parameters.comment_text: The x coordinate of the image.

parameters.name: y
parameters.comment_text: The y coordinate of the image.

methods.name: drawText
methods.comment_text:
Render text to the map using fancy formatting. Newline (\n) characters
 will move down one line and return to the original column, and the text
 color can be changed using sequences such as "12;", replacing 12 with
 the palette index of the color (see {@link MapPalette}).

parameters.name: x
parameters.comment_text: The column to start rendering on.

parameters.name: y
parameters.comment_text: The row to start rendering on.

classes.name: org.bukkit.material.Mushroom
classes.comment_text:
Represents a huge mushroom block with certain combinations of faces set to
 cap, pores or stem.

constructors.name: Mushroom
constructors.comment_text: Constructs a brown/red mushroom block with all sides set to pores.

parameters.name: shroom
parameters.comment_text: A brown or red mushroom material type.

constructors.name: Mushroom
constructors.comment_text:
Constructs a brown/red mushroom cap block with the specified face or
 faces set to cap texture.

 Setting any of the four sides will also set the top to cap.

 To set two side faces at once use e.g. north-west.

 Specify self to set all six faces at once.

parameters.name: shroom
parameters.comment_text: A brown or red mushroom material type.

parameters.name: capFace
parameters.comment_text: The face or faces to set to mushroom cap texture.

constructors.name: Mushroom
constructors.comment_text: Constructs a brown/red mushroom block with the specified textures.

parameters.name: shroom
parameters.comment_text: A brown or red mushroom material type.

methods.name: setStem
methods.comment_text: Sets this to be a mushroom stem.

methods.name: getBlockTexture
methods.comment_text: Gets the mushroom texture of this block.

methods.name: setBlockTexture
methods.comment_text: Sets the mushroom texture of this block.

methods.name: isFacePainted
methods.comment_text: Checks whether a face of the block is painted with cap texture.

methods.name: setFacePainted
methods.comment_text:
Set a face of the block to be painted or not. Note that due to the
 nature of how the data is stored, setting a face painted or not is not
 guaranteed to leave the other faces unchanged.

parameters.name: face
parameters.comment_text: The face to paint or unpaint.

parameters.name: painted
parameters.comment_text:
True if you want to paint it, false if you want the
     pores to show.

Sets the growth state of this crop

classes.name: org.bukkit.metadata.MetadataValueAdapter
classes.comment_text:
Optional base class for facilitating MetadataValue implementations.

This provides all the conversion functions for MetadataValue so that writing an implementation of MetadataValue is as simple as implementing value() and invalidate().

methods.name: value
methods.comment_text: Fetches the value of this metadata item.

methods.name: asInt
methods.comment_text: Attempts to convert the value of this metadata item into an int.

methods.name: asFloat
methods.comment_text: Attempts to convert the value of this metadata item into a float.

methods.name: asDouble
methods.comment_text: Attempts to convert the value of this metadata item into a double.

methods.name: asLong
methods.comment_text: Attempts to convert the value of this metadata item into a long.

methods.name: asShort
methods.comment_text: Attempts to convert the value of this metadata item into a short.

methods.name: asByte
methods.comment_text: Attempts to convert the value of this metadata item into a byte.

methods.name: asBoolean
methods.comment_text: Attempts to convert the value of this metadata item into a boolean.

methods.name: asString
methods.comment_text: Attempts to convert the value of this metadata item into a string.

methods.name: getOwningPlugin
methods.comment_text: Returns the {@link Plugin} that created this metadata item.

methods.name: invalidate
methods.comment_text:
Invalidates this metadata item, forcing it to recompute when next
 accessed.

methods.name: setMetadata
methods.comment_text:
Adds a metadata value to an object. Each metadata value is owned by a specific {@link Plugin}. If a plugin has already added a metadata value to an object, that value will be replaced with the value of {@code newMetadataValue}. Multiple plugins can set independent values for the same {@code metadataKey} without conflict.

Implementation note: I considered using a {@link java.util.concurrent.locks.ReadWriteLock} for controlling access to {@code metadataMap}, but decided that the added overhead wasn't worth the finer grained access control.

Bukkit is almost entirely single threaded so locking overhead shouldn't pose a problem.

parameters.name: metadataKey
parameters.comment_text: A unique key to identify this metadata.

methods.name: getMetadata
methods.comment_text:
Returns all metadata values attached to an object. If multiple
 have attached metadata, each will value will be included.

parameters.name: metadataKey
parameters.comment_text: the unique metadata key being sought.

methods.name: hasMetadata
methods.comment_text: Tests to see if a metadata attribute has been set on an object.

parameters.name: subject
parameters.comment_text:
the object upon which the has-metadata test is
     performed.

parameters.name: metadataKey
parameters.comment_text: the unique metadata key being queried.

methods.name: removeMetadata
methods.comment_text: Removes a metadata item owned by a plugin from a subject.

parameters.name: subject
parameters.comment_text: the object to remove the metadata from.

parameters.name: metadataKey
parameters.comment_text:
the unique metadata key identifying the metadata to
     remove.

parameters.name: owningPlugin
parameters.comment_text: the plugin attempting to remove a metadata item.

methods.name: invalidateAll
methods.comment_text:
Invalidates all metadata in the metadata store that originates from the
 given plugin. Doing this will force each invalidated metadata item to
 be recalculated the next time it is accessed.

methods.name: disambiguate
methods.comment_text:
Creates a unique name for the object receiving metadata by combining unique data from the subject with a metadataKey.

The name created must be globally unique for the given object and any two equivalent objects must generate the same unique name. For example, two Player objects must generate the same string if they represent the same player, even if the objects would fail a reference equality test.

parameters.name: subject
parameters.comment_text: The object for which this key is being generated.

parameters.name: metadataKey
parameters.comment_text: The name identifying the metadata value.

methods.name: setMetadata
methods.comment_text: Adds a metadata value to an object.

parameters.name: metadataKey
parameters.comment_text: A unique key to identify this metadata.

methods.name: getMetadata
methods.comment_text:
Returns all metadata values attached to an object. If multiple plugins
 have attached metadata, each will value will be included.

parameters.name: metadataKey
parameters.comment_text: the unique metadata key being sought.

methods.name: hasMetadata
methods.comment_text: Tests to see if a metadata attribute has been set on an object.

parameters.name: subject
parameters.comment_text:
the object upon which the has-metadata test is
     performed.

parameters.name: metadataKey
parameters.comment_text: the unique metadata key being queried.

methods.name: removeMetadata
methods.comment_text: Removes a metadata item owned by a plugin from a subject.

parameters.name: subject
parameters.comment_text: the object to remove the metadata from.

parameters.name: metadataKey
parameters.comment_text:
the unique metadata key identifying the metadata to
     remove.

parameters.name: owningPlugin
parameters.comment_text: the plugin attempting to remove a metadata item.

methods.name: invalidateAll
methods.comment_text:
Invalidates all metadata in the metadata store that originates from the
 given plugin. Doing this will force each invalidated metadata item to
 be recalculated the next time it is accessed.

classes.name: org.bukkit.metadata.MetadataEvaluationException
classes.comment_text:

 LazyMetadataValue} fails to evaluate its value due to an exception. The
 originating exception will be included as this exception's cause.

A MetadataConversionException is thrown any time a {@link

classes.comment_text:
This interface is implemented by all objects that can provide metadata

parameters.comment_text: the unique metadata key being sought.

Tests to see whether the implementing object contains the given

parameters.name: metadataKey
parameters.comment_text: the unique metadata key being queried.

Removes the given metadata value from the implementing object's
 metadata store.

the unique metadata key identifying the metadata to
     remove.

parameters.name: owningPlugin
parameters.comment_text:
This plugin's metadata value will be removed. All
     other values will be left untouched.

classes.name: org.bukkit.metadata.LazyMetadataValue
classes.comment_text:
The LazyMetadataValue class implements a type of metadata that is not computed until another plugin asks for it.

By making metadata values lazy, no computation is done by the providing plugin until absolutely necessary (if ever). Additionally, LazyMetadataValue objects cache their values internally unless overridden by a {@link CacheStrategy} or invalidated at the individual or plugin level. Once invalidated, the LazyMetadataValue will recompute its value when asked.

constructors.name: LazyMetadataValue
constructors.comment_text:
Initialized a LazyMetadataValue object with the default
 CACHE_AFTER_FIRST_EVAL cache strategy.

parameters.name: owningPlugin
parameters.comment_text:
the {@link Plugin} that created this metadata
     value.

parameters.name: lazyValue
parameters.comment_text: the lazy value assigned to this metadata value.

constructors.name: LazyMetadataValue
constructors.comment_text: Initializes a LazyMetadataValue object with a specific cache strategy.

parameters.name: owningPlugin
parameters.comment_text:
the {@link Plugin} that created this metadata
     value.

parameters.name: cacheStrategy
parameters.comment_text:
determines the rules for caching this metadata
     value.

parameters.name: lazyValue
parameters.comment_text: the lazy value assigned to this metadata value.

constructors.name: LazyMetadataValue
constructors.comment_text:
Protected special constructor used by FixedMetadataValue to bypass
 standard setup.

classes.name: org.bukkit.metadata.LazyMetadataValue.CacheStrategy
classes.comment_text: Describes possible caching strategies for metadata.

classes.name: org.bukkit.metadata.FixedMetadataValue
classes.comment_text:
A FixedMetadataValue is a special case metadata item that contains the same value forever after initialization. Invalidating a FixedMetadataValue has no effect.

This class extends LazyMetadataValue for historical reasons, even though it overrides all the implementation methods. it is possible that in the future that the inheritance hierarchy may change.

constructors.name: FixedMetadataValue
constructors.comment_text: Initializes a FixedMetadataValue with an Object

parameters.name: owningPlugin
parameters.comment_text: the {@link Plugin} that created this metadata value

parameters.name: value
parameters.comment_text: the value assigned to this metadata value

methods.name: loadPermissions
methods.comment_text:
Loads a list of Permissions from a map of data, usually used from retrieval from a yaml file.

The data may contain a list of name:data, where the data contains the following keys:

  • default: Boolean true or false. If not specified, false.
  • children: {@code Map} of child permissions. If not specified, empty list.
  • description: Short string containing a very small description of this description. If not specified, empty string.

parameters.comment_text: An error message to show if a permission is invalid.

parameters.name: def
parameters.comment_text: Default permission value to use if missing

Manages services and service providers. Services are an interface
 specifying a list of methods that a provider must implement. Providers are
 implementations of these services. A provider can be queried from the
 services manager in order to use a service (if one is available). If
 multiple plugins register a service, then the service with the highest
 priority takes precedence.

classes.name: org.bukkit.plugin.PluginDescriptionFile
classes.comment_text:
This type is the runtime-container for the information in the plugin.yml. All plugins must have a respective plugin.yml. For plugins written in java using the standard plugin loader, this file must be in the root of the jar file.

When Bukkit loads a plugin, it needs to know some basic information about it. It reads this information from a YAML file, 'plugin.yml'. This file consists of a set of attributes, each defined on a new line and with no indentation.

Every (almost* every) method corresponds with a specific entry in the plugin.yml. These are the required entries for every plugin.yml:

  • {@link #getName()} - name
  • {@link #getVersion()} - version
  • {@link #getMain()} - main

Failing to include any of these items will throw an exception and cause the server to ignore your plugin.

This is a list of the possible yaml keys, with specific details included in the respective method documentations:
The description of the plugin.yml layout
Node Method Summary
name {@link #getName()} The unique name of plugin
version {@link #getVersion()} A plugin revision identifier
main {@link #getMain()} The plugin's initial class file
author
authors		 {@link #getAuthors()} The plugin contributors
description {@link #getDescription()} Human readable plugin summary
website {@link #getWebsite()} The URL to the plugin's site
prefix {@link #getPrefix()} The token to prefix plugin log entries
load {@link #getLoad()} The phase of server-startup this plugin will load during
depend {@link #getDepend()} Other required plugins
softdepend {@link #getSoftDepend()} Other plugins that add functionality
loadbefore {@link #getLoadBefore()} The inverse softdepend
commands {@link #getCommands()} The commands the plugin will register
permissions {@link #getPermissions()} The permissions the plugin will register
default-permission {@link #getPermissionDefault()} The default {@link Permission#getDefault() default} permission state for defined {@link #getPermissions() permissions} the plugin will register
awareness {@link #getAwareness()} The concepts that the plugin acknowledges
api-version {@link #getAPIVersion()} The API version which this plugin was programmed against

A plugin.yml example:

name: Inferno
version: 1.4.1
description: This plugin is so 31337. You can set yourself on fire.
# We could place every author in the authors list, but chose not to for illustrative purposes
# Also, having an author distinguishes that person as the project lead, and ensures their
# name is displayed first
author: CaptainInflamo
authors: [Cogito, verrier, EvilSeph]
website: http://www.curse.com/server-mods/minecraft/myplugin

main: com.captaininflamo.bukkit.inferno.Inferno
depend: [NewFire, FlameWire]
api-version: 1.13

commands:
  flagrate:
    description: Set yourself on fire.
    aliases: [combust_me, combustMe]
    permission: inferno.flagrate
    usage: Syntax error! Simply type /<command> to ignite yourself.
  burningdeaths:
    description: List how many times you have died by fire.
    aliases: [burning_deaths, burningDeaths]
    permission: inferno.burningdeaths
    usage: |
      /<command> [player]
      Example: /<command> - see how many times you have burned to death
      Example: /<command> CaptainIce - see how many times CaptainIce has burned to death

permissions:
  inferno.*:
    description: Gives access to all Inferno commands
    children:
      inferno.flagrate: true
      inferno.burningdeaths: true
      inferno.burningdeaths.others: true
  inferno.flagrate:
    description: Allows you to ignite yourself
    default: true
  inferno.burningdeaths:
    description: Allows you to see how many times you have burned to death
    default: true
  inferno.burningdeaths.others:
    description: Allows you to see how many times others have burned to death
    default: op
    children:
      inferno.burningdeaths: true

If the PluginDescriptionFile is

constructors.name: PluginDescriptionFile
constructors.comment_text: Creates a new PluginDescriptionFile with the given detailed

parameters.name: mainClass
parameters.comment_text: Full location of the main class of this plugin

methods.name: getName
methods.comment_text:
Gives the name of the plugin. This name is a unique identifier for plugins.
  • Must consist of all alphanumeric characters, underscores, hyphon, and period (a-z,A-Z,0-9, _.-). Any other character will cause the plugin.yml to fail loading.
  • Used to determine the name of the plugin's data folder. Data folders are placed in the ./plugins/ directory by default, but this behavior should not be relied on. {@link Plugin#getDataFolder()} should be used to reference the data folder.
  • It is good practice to name your jar the same as this, for example 'MyPlugin.jar'.
  • Case sensitive.
  • The is the token referenced in {@link #getDepend()}, {@link #getSoftDepend()}, and {@link #getLoadBefore()}.
  • Using spaces in the plugin's name is deprecated.

In the plugin.yml, this entry is named name.

Example:

name: MyPlugin

methods.name: getVersion
methods.comment_text:
Gives the version of the plugin.
  • Version is an arbitrary string, however the most common format is MajorRelease.MinorRelease.Build (eg: 1.4.1).
  • Typically you will increment this every time you release a new feature or bug fix.
  • Displayed when a user types /version PluginName

In the plugin.yml, this entry is named version.

Example:

version: 1.4.1

methods.name: getMain
methods.comment_text:
Gives the fully qualified name of the main class for a plugin. The format should follow the {@link ClassLoader#loadClass(String)} syntax to successfully be resolved at runtime. For most plugins, this is the class that extends {@link JavaPlugin}.
  • This must contain the full namespace including the class file itself.
  • If your namespace is org.bukkit.plugin, and your class file is called MyPlugin then this must be org.bukkit.plugin.MyPlugin
  • No plugin can use org.bukkit. as a base package for any class, including the main class.

In the plugin.yml, this entry is named main.

Example: 

main: org.bukkit.plugin.MyPlugin

methods.name: getDescription
methods.comment_text:
Gives a human-friendly description of the functionality the plugin provides.
  • The description can have multiple lines.
  • Displayed when a user types /version PluginName

In the plugin.yml, this entry is named description.

Example: 

description: This plugin is so 31337. You can set yourself on fire.

methods.name: getLoad
methods.comment_text:
Gives the phase of server startup that the plugin should be loaded.
  • Possible values are in {@link PluginLoadOrder}.
  • Defaults to {@link PluginLoadOrder#POSTWORLD}.
  • Certain caveats apply to each phase.
  • When different, {@link #getDepend()}, {@link #getSoftDepend()}, and {@link #getLoadBefore()} become relative in order loaded per-phase. If a plugin loads at STARTUP, but a dependency loads at POSTWORLD, the dependency will not be loaded before the plugin is loaded.

In the plugin.yml, this entry is named load.

Example:

load: STARTUP

methods.name: getAuthors
methods.comment_text:
Gives the list of authors for the plugin.
  • Gives credit to the developer.
  • Used in some server error messages to provide helpful feedback on who to contact when an error occurs.
  • A bukkit.org forum handle or email address is recommended.
  • Is displayed when a user types /version PluginName
  • authors must be in YAML list format.

In the plugin.yml, this has two entries, author and authors.

Single author example: 

author: CaptainInflamo
Multiple author example: 
authors: [Cogito, verrier, EvilSeph]
When both are specified, author will be the first entry in the list, so this example: 
author: Grum
authors:
- feildmaster
- amaranth
Is equivilant to this example: 
authors: [Grum, feildmaster, aramanth]

methods.name: getWebsite
methods.comment_text:
Gives the plugin's or plugin's author's website.
  • A link to the Curse page that includes documentation and downloads is highly recommended.
  • Displayed when a user types /version PluginName

In the plugin.yml, this entry is named website.

Example: 

website: http://www.curse.com/server-mods/minecraft/myplugin

methods.name: getDepend
methods.comment_text:
Gives a list of other plugins that the plugin requires.
  • Use the value in the {@link #getName()} of the target plugin to specify the dependency.
  • If any plugin listed here is not found, your plugin will fail to load at startup.
  • If multiple plugins list each other in depend, creating a network with no individual plugin does not list another plugin in the network, all plugins in that network will fail.
  • depend must be in must be in YAML list format.

In the plugin.yml, this entry is named depend.

Example: 

depend:
- OnePlugin
- AnotherPlugin

methods.name: getSoftDepend
methods.comment_text:
Gives a list of other plugins that the plugin requires for full functionality. The {@link PluginManager} will make best effort to treat all entries here as if they were a {@link #getDepend() dependency}, but will never fail because of one of these entries.
  • Use the value in the {@link #getName()} of the target plugin to specify the dependency.
  • When an unresolvable plugin is listed, it will be ignored and does not affect load order.
  • When a circular dependency occurs (a network of plugins depending or soft-dependending each other), it will arbitrarily choose a plugin that can be resolved when ignoring soft-dependencies.
  • softdepend must be in YAML list format.

In the plugin.yml, this entry is named softdepend.

Example: 

softdepend: [OnePlugin, AnotherPlugin]

methods.name: getLoadBefore
methods.comment_text:
Gets the list of plugins that should consider this plugin a soft-dependency.
  • Use the value in the {@link #getName()} of the target plugin to specify the dependency.
  • The plugin should load before any other plugins listed here.
  • Specifying another plugin here is strictly equivalent to having the specified plugin's {@link #getSoftDepend()} include {@link #getName() this plugin}.
  • loadbefore must be in YAML list format.

In the plugin.yml, this entry is named loadbefore.

Example: 

loadbefore:
- OnePlugin
- AnotherPlugin

methods.name: getPrefix
methods.comment_text:
Gives the token to prefix plugin-specific logging messages with.
  • This includes all messages using {@link Plugin#getLogger()}.
  • If not specified, the server uses the plugin's {@link #getName() name}.
  • This should clearly indicate what plugin is being logged.

In the plugin.yml, this entry is named prefix.

Example:

prefix: ex-why-zee

methods.name: getCommands
methods.comment_text:
Gives the map of command-name to command-properties. Each entry in this map corresponds to a single command and the respective values are the properties of the command. Each property, with the exception of aliases, can be defined at runtime using methods in {@link PluginCommand} and are defined here only as a convenience.
The command section's description
Node Method Type Description Example
description {@link PluginCommand#setDescription(String)} String A user-friendly description for a command. It is useful for documentation purposes as well as in-game help. 
description: Set yourself on fire
aliases {@link PluginCommand#setAliases(List)} String or List of strings Alternative command names, with special usefulness for commands that are already registered. Aliases are not effective when defined at runtime, so the plugin description file is the only way to have them properly defined.

Note: Command aliases may not have a colon in them.

 Single alias format: 
aliases: combust_me
or multiple alias format: 
aliases: [combust_me, combustMe]
permission {@link PluginCommand#setPermission(String)} String The name of the {@link Permission} required to use the command. A user without the permission will receive the specified message (see {@linkplain PluginCommand#setPermissionMessage(String) below}), or a standard one if no specific message is defined. Without the permission node, no {@link PluginCommand#setExecutor(CommandExecutor) CommandExecutor} or {@link PluginCommand#setTabCompleter(TabCompleter) TabCompleter} will be called. 
permission: inferno.flagrate
permission-message {@link PluginCommand#setPermissionMessage(String)} String
  • Displayed to a player that attempts to use a command, but does not have the required permission. See {@link PluginCommand#getPermission() above}.
  • <permission> is a macro that is replaced with the permission node required to use the command.
  • Using empty quotes is a valid way to indicate nothing should be displayed to a player. 
permission-message: You do not have /<permission>
usage {@link PluginCommand#setUsage(String)} String This message is displayed to a player when the {@link PluginCommand#setExecutor(CommandExecutor)} {@linkplain CommandExecutor#onCommand(CommandSender,Command,String,String[]) returns false}. <command> is a macro that is replaced the command issued. 
usage: Syntax error! Perhaps you meant /<command> PlayerName?
It is worth noting that to use a colon in a yaml, like `usage: Usage: /god [player]', you need to surround the message with double-quote: 
usage: "Usage: /god [player]"
The commands are structured as a hiearchy of nested mappings. The primary (top-level, no intendentation) node is `commands', while each individual command name is indented, indicating it maps to some value (in our case, the properties of the table above).

Here is an example bringing together the piecemeal examples above, as well as few more definitions:

commands:
  flagrate:
    description: Set yourself on fire.
    aliases: [combust_me, combustMe]
    permission: inferno.flagrate
    permission-message: You do not have /<permission>
    usage: Syntax error! Perhaps you meant /<command> PlayerName?
  burningdeaths:
    description: List how many times you have died by fire.
    aliases:
    - burning_deaths
    - burningDeaths
    permission: inferno.burningdeaths
    usage: |
      /<command> [player]
      Example: /<command> - see how many times you have burned to death
      Example: /<command> CaptainIce - see how many times CaptainIce has burned to death
  # The next command has no description, aliases, etc. defined, but is still valid
  # Having an empty declaration is useful for defining the description, permission, and messages from a configuration dynamically
  apocalypse:
Note: Command names may not have a colon in their name.

methods.name: getPermissions
methods.comment_text:
Gives the list of permissions the plugin will register at runtime, immediately proceding enabling. The format for defining permissions is a map from permission name to properties. To represent a map without any specific property, empty curly-braces ( {} ) may be used (as a null value is not accepted, unlike the {@link #getCommands() commands} above).

A list of optional properties for permissions:
The permission section's description
Node Description Example
description Plaintext (user-friendly) description of what the permission is for. 
description: Allows you to set yourself on fire
default The default state for the permission, as defined by {@link Permission#getDefault()}. If not defined, it will be set to the value of {@link PluginDescriptionFile#getPermissionDefault()}.

For reference:

  • true - Represents a positive assignment to {@link Permissible permissibles}.
  • false - Represents no assignment to {@link Permissible permissibles}.
  • op - Represents a positive assignment to {@link Permissible#isOp() operator permissibles}.
  • notop - Represents a positive assignment to {@link Permissible#isOp() non-operator permissibiles}. 
default: true
children Allows other permissions to be set as a {@linkplain Permission#getChildren() relation} to the parent permission. When a parent permissions is assigned, child permissions are respectively assigned as well.
  • When a parent permission is assigned negatively, child permissions are assigned based on an inversion of their association.
  • When a parent permission is assigned positively, child permissions are assigned based on their association.

Child permissions may be defined in a number of ways:

  • Children may be defined as a list of names. Using a list will treat all children associated positively to their parent.
  • Children may be defined as a map. Each permission name maps to either a boolean (representing the association), or a nested permission definition (just as another permission). Using a nested definition treats the child as a positive association.
  • A nested permission definition must be a map of these same properties. To define a valid nested permission without defining any specific property, empty curly-braces ( {} ) must be used.
  • A nested permission may carry it's own nested permissions as children, as they may also have nested permissions, and so forth. There is no direct limit to how deep the permission tree is defined.
As a list: 
children: [inferno.flagrate, inferno.burningdeaths]
Or as a mapping: 
children:
  inferno.flagrate: true
  inferno.burningdeaths: true
An additional example showing basic nested values can be seen here.
The permissions are structured as a hiearchy of nested mappings. The primary (top-level, no intendentation) node is `permissions', while each individual permission name is indented, indicating it maps to some value (in our case, the properties of the table above).

Here is an example using some of the properties:

permissions:
  inferno.*:
    description: Gives access to all Inferno commands
    children:
      inferno.flagrate: true
      inferno.burningdeaths: true
  inferno.flagate:
    description: Allows you to ignite yourself
    default: true
  inferno.burningdeaths:
    description: Allows you to see how many times you have burned to death
    default: true
Another example, with nested definitions, can be found here.

methods.name: getPermissionDefault
methods.comment_text:
Gives the default {@link Permission#getDefault() default} state of {@link #getPermissions() permissions} registered for the plugin.
  • If not specified, it will be {@link PermissionDefault#OP}.
  • It is matched using {@link PermissionDefault#getByName(String)}
  • It only affects permissions that do not define the default node.
  • It may be any value in {@link PermissionDefault}.

In the plugin.yml, this entry is named default-permission.

Example:

default-permission: NOT_OP

methods.name: getAwareness
methods.comment_text:
Gives a set of every {@link PluginAwareness} for a plugin. An awareness dictates something that a plugin developer acknowledges when the plugin is compiled. Some implementions may define extra awarenesses that are not included in the API. Any unrecognized awareness (one unsupported or in a future version) will cause a dummy object to be created instead of failing.
  • Currently only supports the enumerated values in {@link PluginAwareness.Flags}.
  • Each awareness starts the identifier with bang-at (!@).
  • Unrecognized (future / unimplemented) entries are quietly replaced by a generic object that implements PluginAwareness.
  • A type of awareness must be defined by the runtime and acknowledged by the API, effectively discluding any derived type from any plugin's classpath.
  • awareness must be in YAML list format.

In the plugin.yml, this entry is named awareness.

Example:

awareness:
- !@UTF8

Note: Although unknown versions of some future awareness are gracefully substituted, previous versions of Bukkit (ones prior to the first implementation of awareness) will fail to load a plugin that defines any awareness.

methods.name: getFullName
methods.comment_text:
Returns the name of a plugin, including the version. This method is
 provided for convenience; it uses the {@link #getName()} and {@link
 #getVersion()} entries.

methods.name: getAPIVersion
methods.comment_text:
Gives the API version which this plugin is designed to support. No specific format is guaranteed.
  • Refer to release notes for supported API versions.

In the plugin.yml, this entry is named api-version.

Example:

api-version: 1.13

Represents a concept that a plugin is aware of.

The internal representation may be singleton, or be a parameterized instance, but must be immutable.

Each entry here represents a particular plugin's awareness. These can

 Set#contains(Object) contains(flag)}.

Gets a {@link FileConfiguration} for this plugin, read through "config.yml"

If there is a default config.yml embedded in this plugin, it will be provided as a default for this Configuration.

Saves the raw contents of the default config.yml file to the location retrievable by {@link #getConfig()}.

This should fail silently if the config.yml already exists.

methods.name: saveResource
methods.comment_text:
Saves the raw contents of any resource embedded with a plugin's .jar file assuming it can be found using {@link #getResource(String)}.

The resource is saved into the plugin's data folder using the same hierarchy as the .jar file (subdirectories are preserved).

parameters.name: resourcePath
parameters.comment_text:
the embedded resource path to look for within the
     plugin's .jar file. (No preceding slash).

parameters.name: replace
parameters.comment_text:
if true, the embedded resource will overwrite the
     contents of an existing file.

methods.name: reloadConfig
methods.comment_text: Discards any data in {@link #getConfig()} and reloads from disk.

Called after a plugin is loaded but before it has been enabled.

When multiple plugins are loaded, the onLoad() for all plugins is called before any onEnable() is called.

Returns the plugin logger associated with this server's logger. The
 returned logger automatically tags all log messages with the plugin's

methods.name: getName

This should return the bare name of the plugin and should be used for comparison.

methods.name: getPlugin

This method provides fast access to the plugin that has {@link #getProvidingPlugin(Class) provided} the given plugin class, which is usually the plugin that implemented it.

An exception to this would be if plugin's jar that contained the class does not extend the class, where the intended plugin would have resided in a different jar / classloader.

The message may not be larger than {@link Messenger#MAX_MESSAGE_SIZE} bytes, and the plugin must be registered to send messages on the specified channel.

parameters.name: channel
